text.tspan: This formalism also gives us a meaningful
way to put boundary conditions at infinity.
It can be shown that if you try to take the
overlap between the cat state (all up plus
all down) and the Z state (sum over all
configurations with one up and the rest
down) then you get the function f(N)=1
when N=1 and 0 otherwise, despite the
fact that intuitively the two states should
have zero overlap --- that's no good!
The fix is to let the expectation function be:
That is, we use the L and R tensors as we did
when computing the expectation values of
the state families. This in particular tells us
should be selected to appear in the
expectation function and with what weights.
if for all N ∃ K>N s.t.
